FacilityName: City of Starke Wastewater Treatment Plant

_exec_summary.SummaryText:
EXECUTIVE SUMMARY

Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Policies:
At the City of Starke Wastewater Treatment Plant (WWTP) we store and use chlorine gas, which is considered hazardous by the Environmental Protection Agency (EPA).  Because our storage of chlorine exceeds the 2,500-pound threshold, we develop and implement a Risk Management Plan as required by the regulations under the EPA 40 CFT 68.  

It is necessary to observe certain safety precautions in handling chlorine to prevent unnecessary human exposure, to reduce the threat to our employees, and to reduce the threat to nearby members of the community.  It is our policy to implement appropriate controls to prevent possible releases of chlorine and to adhere to all applicable federal and state rules and regulations.  Safety depends on proper handling of chlorine, which requires proper training, combined with the safety devices installed in the system.

Our Emergency Response Program is based on the plan developed by the District 3 Local Emergency Planning council.  The Emergency Response Plan includes procedures for notification of the local fire authority and evacuation routes.

Stationary Source and Regulated Substances Handled:
We have one regulated substance present at our facility, chlorine gas.  Chlorine gas is used in the final stage of the wastewater treatment process to disinfect the effluent.  The gas is stored in one-ton cylinders.  At this time, the maximum inventory of chlorine gas at our facility is 2 one-ton cylinders, for a total of 4,000 pounds.

General Accidental Release Prevention Program and the Specific Prevention Steps:
This facility complies with EPA?s Accidental Release Prevention Rule and with all applicable state codes and regulations.  This plant was designed and constructed in accordance with all relevant standards including:  Technical Bulletin ? Design Criteria for Mechanical, Electrical, and Fluid Systems and Component Reliability ? Supplement to Federal Guideli

nes for Design, Operation and Maintenance of Wastewater Facilities, 1974 Edition; Recommended Standards for Wastewater Facilities (Ten State Standards), 1990 Edition; and all relevant Florida Department of Environmental Protection (DEP) standards.

All of our employees have been thoroughly trained in the proper and safe handling of chlorine and we maintain a detailed record of safety information that describes the hazards, operating procedures and parameters, and equipment designs associated with chlorine gas.

Five-year Accident History:
The City of Starke WWTP has not had any accidents in the last five years, as of October 1, 2004.

Emergency Response Program:
The plant?s Emergency Response Program is based on the plan developed by the District 3 Local Emergency Planning Council.  The Emergency Response Plan includes procedures for notification of the local fire authority and evacuation routes.

Planned Changes to Improve Safety:
Currently there are no planned changes for the chlorine storage and handling at this facility.  We will continue to monitor and inspect all aspects of chlorine use to determine if any changes would improve safety.
